Key Arguments: The Bill enables government and big tech companies to silence and censor speech that disagrees with the government narrative.
It gives governments the power to silence religious and political speech that contradicts prevailing ideologies.
There are no mechanisms in the Bill to protect valid expression of opinion and belief.
The Bill is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication under international human rights instruments.
The Bill gives excessive power to unelected bureaucrats without transparency or accountability.
Excluding government-authorized content from censorship is hypocritical and inconsistent with democratic values.
The penalties for non-compliance are excessive and will have a chilling effect on free speech.
Notable Quotes: This Bill enables government bureaucrats and big tech companies to silence and censor speech that differs or disagrees with the government narrative.
This Bill is, to put it simply, significant overreach by the government.
Excluding government-authorised content from this censorship regime is hypocritical and inconsistent with the values one would expect in a democratic country.
Professor Noam Chomskyâ€™s quote sums up my concerns of this Bill: 'If you believe in freedom of speech, you believe in freedom of speech for views you don't like.'
